trans-unit.source: Web App with Express (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Web App with Express (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that builds on the cloud service tutorial, and demonstrates how to use the Express module.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that builds on the cloud service tutorial, and demonstrates how to use the Express module.

trans-unit.source: Build a Node.js web application using Express on an Azure Cloud Service
trans-unit.target: Build a Node.js web application using Express on an Azure Cloud Service

trans-unit.source: Node.js includes a minimal set of functionality in the core runtime.
trans-unit.target: Node.js includes a minimal set of functionality in the core runtime.

trans-unit.source: Developers often use 3rd party modules to provide additional
trans-unit.target: Developers often use 3rd party modules to provide additional

trans-unit.source: functionality when developing a Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: functionality when developing a Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial

trans-unit.source: you will create a new application using the [Express][] module, which provides an MVC framework for creating Node.js web applications.
trans-unit.target: you will create a new application using the [Express][] module, which provides an MVC framework for creating Node.js web applications.

trans-unit.source: A screenshot of the completed application is below:
trans-unit.target: A screenshot of the completed application is below:

trans-unit.source: A web browser displaying Welcome to Express in Azure
trans-unit.target: A web browser displaying Welcome to Express in Azure

trans-unit.source: Create a Cloud Service Project
trans-unit.target: Create a Cloud Service Project

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to create a new cloud service project named 'expressapp':
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to create a new cloud service project named 'expressapp':

trans-unit.source: From the **Start Menu** or **Start Screen**, search for **Azure PowerShell**.
trans-unit.target: From the **Start Menu** or **Start Screen**, search for **Azure PowerShell**.

trans-unit.source: Finally, right-click **Azure PowerShell** and select **Run As Administrator**.
trans-unit.target: Finally, right-click **Azure PowerShell** and select **Run As Administrator**.

trans-unit.source: Azure PowerShell icon
trans-unit.target: Azure PowerShell icon

trans-unit.source: Change directories to the **c:\\node** directory and then enter the following commands to create a new solution named **expressapp** and a web role named **WebRole1**:
trans-unit.target: Change directories to the **c:\\node** directory and then enter the following commands to create a new solution named **expressapp** and a web role named **WebRole1**:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, **Add-AzureNodeWebRole** uses an older version of Node.js.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, **Add-AzureNodeWebRole** uses an older version of Node.js.

trans-unit.source: The **Set-AzureServiceProjectRole** statement above instructs Azure to use v0.10.21 of Node.
trans-unit.target: The **Set-AzureServiceProjectRole** statement above instructs Azure to use v0.10.21 of Node.

trans-unit.source: Note the parameters are case-sensitive.
trans-unit.target: Note the parameters are case-sensitive.

trans-unit.source: You can verify the correct version of Node.js has been selected by checking the **engines** property in **WebRole1\package.json**.
trans-unit.target: You can verify the correct version of Node.js has been selected by checking the **engines** property in **WebRole1\package.json**.

trans-unit.source: Install Express
trans-unit.target: Install Express

trans-unit.source: Install the Express generator by issuing the following command:
trans-unit.target: Install the Express generator by issuing the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output of the npm command should look similar to the result below.
trans-unit.target: The output of the npm command should look similar to the result below.

trans-unit.source: Windows PowerShell displaying the output of the npm install express command.
trans-unit.target: Windows PowerShell displaying the output of the npm install express command.

trans-unit.source: Change directories to the **WebRole1** directory and use the express command to generate a new application:
trans-unit.target: Change directories to the **WebRole1** directory and use the express command to generate a new application:

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to overwrite your earlier application.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to overwrite your earlier application.

trans-unit.source: Enter **y** or **yes** to continue.
trans-unit.target: Enter **y** or **yes** to continue.

trans-unit.source: Express will generate the app.js file and a folder structure for building your application.
trans-unit.target: Express will generate the app.js file and a folder structure for building your application.

trans-unit.source: The output of the express command
trans-unit.target: The output of the express command

trans-unit.source: To install additional dependencies defined in the package.json file,
trans-unit.target: To install additional dependencies defined in the package.json file,

trans-unit.source: enter the following command:
trans-unit.target: enter the following command:

trans-unit.source: The output of the npm install command
trans-unit.target: The output of the npm install command

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to copy the **bin/www** file to **server.js**.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to copy the **bin/www** file to **server.js**.

trans-unit.source: This is so the cloud service can find the entry point for this application.
trans-unit.target: This is so the cloud service can find the entry point for this application.

trans-unit.source: After this command completes, you should have a **server.js** file in the WebRole1 directory.
trans-unit.target: After this command completes, you should have a **server.js** file in the WebRole1 directory.

trans-unit.source: Modify the **server.js** to remove one of the '.' characters from the following line.
trans-unit.target: Modify the **server.js** to remove one of the '.' characters from the following line.

trans-unit.source: After making this modification, the line should appear as follows.
trans-unit.target: After making this modification, the line should appear as follows.

trans-unit.source: This change is required since we moved the file (formerly **bin/www**,) to the same directory as the app file being required.
trans-unit.target: This change is required since we moved the file (formerly **bin/www**,) to the same directory as the app file being required.

trans-unit.source: After making this change, save the **server.js** file.
trans-unit.target: After making this change, save the **server.js** file.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to run the application in the Azure emulator:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to run the application in the Azure emulator:

trans-unit.source: A web page containing welcome to express.
trans-unit.target: A web page containing welcome to express.

trans-unit.source: Modifying the View
trans-unit.target: Modifying the View

trans-unit.source: Now modify the view to display the message "Welcome to Express in
trans-unit.target: Now modify the view to display the message "Welcome to Express in

trans-unit.source: Azure".
trans-unit.target: Azure".

trans-unit.source: Enter the following command to open the index.jade file:
trans-unit.target: Enter the following command to open the index.jade file:

trans-unit.source: The contents of the index.jade file.
trans-unit.target: The contents of the index.jade file.

trans-unit.source: Jade is the default view engine used by Express applications.
trans-unit.target: Jade is the default view engine used by Express applications.

trans-unit.source: For more
trans-unit.target: For more

trans-unit.source: information on the Jade view engine, see [http://jade-lang.com][].
trans-unit.target: information on the Jade view engine, see [http://jade-lang.com][].

trans-unit.source: Modify the last line of text by appending **in Azure**.
trans-unit.target: Modify the last line of text by appending **in Azure**.

trans-unit.source: The index.jade file, the last line reads: p Welcome to \#{title} in Azure
trans-unit.target: The index.jade file, the last line reads: p Welcome to \#{title} in Azure

trans-unit.source: Save the file and exit Notepad.
trans-unit.target: Save the file and exit Notepad.

trans-unit.source: Refresh your browser and you will see your changes.
trans-unit.target: Refresh your browser and you will see your changes.

trans-unit.source: A browser window, the page contains Welcome to Express in Azure
trans-unit.target: A browser window, the page contains Welcome to Express in Azure

trans-unit.source: After testing the application, use the **Stop-AzureEmulator** cmdlet to stop the emulator.
trans-unit.target: After testing the application, use the **Stop-AzureEmulator** cmdlet to stop the emulator.

trans-unit.source: Publishing the Application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Publishing the Application to Azure

trans-unit.source: In the Azure PowerShell window, use the **Publish-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet to deploy the application to a cloud service
trans-unit.target: In the Azure PowerShell window, use the **Publish-AzureServiceProject** cmdlet to deploy the application to a cloud service

trans-unit.source: Once the deployment operation completes, your browser will open and display the web page.
trans-unit.target: Once the deployment operation completes, your browser will open and display the web page.

trans-unit.source: A web browser displaying the Express page.
trans-unit.target: A web browser displaying the Express page.

trans-unit.source: The URL indicates it is now hosted on Azure.
trans-unit.target: The URL indicates it is now hosted on Azure.

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
